messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 49 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: From Play to Policy: Conditional Behavior Generation from Uncurated Robot Data

Paper Abstract: Abstract While large-scale sequence modeling from offline data has led to impressive performance gains in natural language and image generation, directly translating such ideas to robotics has been challenging. One critical reason for this is that uncurated robot demonstration data, i.e. play data, collected from non-expert human demonstrators are often noisy, diverse, and distributionally multi-modal. This makes extracting useful, task-centric behaviors from such data a difficult generative modeling problem. In this work, we present Conditional Behavior Transformers (C-BeT), a method that combines the multi-modal generation ability of Behavior Transformer with future-conditioned goal specification. On a suite of simulated benchmark tasks, we find that C-BeT improves upon prior state-of-the-art work in learning from play data by an average of 45.7%percent45.745.7\%. Further, we demonstrate for the first time that useful task-centric behaviors can be learned on a real-world robot purely from play data without any task labels or reward information. Robot videos are best viewed on our project website: play-to-policy.github.io.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 49 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 49"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Hindsight experience replay",
        "A survey of robot learning from demonstration",
        "When does return-conditioned supervised learning work for offline reinforcement learning?",
        "Language models are few-shot learners",
        "Decision transformer: Reinforcement learning via sequence modeling",
        "Assistive tele-op: Leveraging transformers to collect robotic task demonstrations",
        "Transformers for one-shot visual imitation",
        "Carla: An open urban driving simulator",
        "One-shot imitation learning",
        "Rvs: What is essential for offline rl via supervised learning?",
        "Contrastive learning as goal-conditioned reinforcement learning",
        "Implicit behavioral cloning",
        "D4rl: Datasets for deep data-driven reinforcement learning",
        "Learning to reach goals via iterated supervised learning",
        "Fast r-cnn",
        "Retrieval-augmented reinforcement learning",
        "Bootstrap your own latent-a new approach to self-supervised learning",
        "Relay policy learning: Solving long-horizon tasks via imitation and reinforcement learning",
        "Bootstrapped autonomous practicing via multi-task reinforcement learning",
        "Deep residual learning for image recognition",
        "Generative adversarial imitation learning",
        "Offline reinforcement learning as one big sequence modeling problem",
        "Learning to achieve goals",
        "Offline reinforcement learning with fisher divergence critic regularization",
        "Offline reinforcement learning: Tutorial, review, and perspectives on open problems",
        "Learning multi-level hierarchies with hindsight",
        "Focal loss for dense object detection",
        "Energy-based imitation learning",
        "Learning latent plans from play",
        "How far i‚Äôll go: Offline goal-conditioned reinforcement learning via fùëìf-advantage regression",
        "Towards more generalizable one-shot visual imitation learning",
        "Learning to Generalize Across Long-Horizon Tasks from Human Demonstrations",
        "Provable representation learning for imitation with contrastive fourier features",
        "Data-efficient hierarchical reinforcement learning",
        "Algorithms for inverse reinforcement learning",
        "The surprising effectiveness of representation learning for visual imitation",
        "You can‚Äôt count on luck: Why decision transformers fail in stochastic environments",
        "Accelerating reinforcement learning with learned skill priors",
        "Vision-based multi-task manipulation for inexpensive robots using end-to-end learning from demonstration",
        "Hierarchical text-conditional image generation with clip latents",
        "Learning agents for uncertain environments",
        "Universal value function approximators",
        "Behavior transformers: Cloning kùëòk modes with one stone",
        "Parrot: Data-driven behavioral priors for reinforcement learning",
        "Many-goals reinforcement learning",
        "Rethinking goal-conditioned supervised learning and its connection to offline rl",
        "Playful interactions for representation learning",
        "Deep imitation learning for complex manipulation tasks from virtual reality teleoperation",
        "Maximum entropy-regularized multi-goal reinforcement learning"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 49 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in From Play to Policy: Conditional Behavior Generation from Uncurated Robot Data, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
